description: There are a lot of different technologies that can be used to keep data more secure in Windows 10 including NTFS permissions, which controls the level of access someone has and the kind of actions one can perform on different files. The topics that are covered range from data security, host security, application management to recovery of the operating system. This is designed for a broad range of individuals including help-desk technicians to the average end-user seeking to implement a more secure Windows 10 environment.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes continue detailing how to secure data using permissions on a Windows 10 machine, this time showing you how to check the effective permissions of a user or group. Then they show you how to enable the Encrypting File System to encrypt data on an NTFS volume. Finally they discuss using Data Execution Protection(DEP) to stop malicious software from being executed.

00:08:56.240 --> 00:08:58.850
So when the next time

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes show you how to create a more fundamentally secure environment in Windows 10 by implementing local group policy. Here they explain what local group policy is, how to configure it, and some of the ways that you can secure your PC, like restricting access to the registry. They also show you how to create multiple policies for applying different levels of access depending on user roles (admins vs. standard users).

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Daniel explain how to stay safe in the wilds of the internet by taking advantage of the features found in your web browser; specifically Internet Explorer and Edge. 00:32:42.440 --> 00:32:49.029
we'll see you next time.
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore security in your Windows 10 PC through account management. Here they explain the different types of accounts such as Local, Domain, and Microsoft account along with the difference between administrative and non-administrative. They also describe built-in access control called the User Account Control(UAC) mechanism as well as how to configure the UAC.
episodes.title: Account Management
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:10.000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:12.039 --> 00:00:16.963
All right, greetings everyone and welcome
to another exciting episode of ITPro TV.

3
00:00:16.963 --> 00:00:21.048
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and in today's
show, we're gonna be moving on with some

4
00:00:21.048 --> 00:00:24.540
more Windows 10 security,
specifically account management.

5
00:00:24.540 --> 00:00:27.780
And joining me in the studio today
to help lend his expertise on

6
00:00:27.780 --> 00:00:29.780
that subject is none
other than Mr Wes Bryan.

7
00:00:29.780 --> 00:00:30.670
How's it going today, Wes?

8
00:00:30.670 --> 00:00:31.370
>> Man, it's going great.

9
00:00:31.370 --> 00:00:32.680
It's great to be here today.

10
00:00:32.680 --> 00:00:35.020
And in fact, we've got some
very cool stuff to talk about.

11
00:00:35.020 --> 00:00:38.720
The different types of accounts that you
can see in your Windows 10 environment.

12
00:00:38.720 --> 00:00:42.920
And we're gonna start out by maybe
distinguishing the difference between

13
00:00:42.920 --> 00:00:45.180
what's known as a standard account and

14
00:00:45.180 --> 00:00:47.470
what is known as
an administrative account.

15
00:00:47.470 --> 00:00:49.600
Now you might see that in
other operating systems,

16
00:00:49.600 --> 00:00:51.620
they might not call it
a standard user account.

17
00:00:51.620 --> 00:00:59.009
Windows does tend to name some things
different than the rest of the world.

18
00:00:59.009 --> 00:00:59.710
You might hear it called
non admin account.

19
00:00:59.710 --> 00:01:01.380
In other operating systems,

20
00:01:01.380 --> 00:01:05.970
they might talk about an administrative
account being a root user.

21
00:01:05.970 --> 00:01:08.146
In Windows, let's see if we
can distinguish the difference

22
00:01:08.146 --> 00:01:08.793
between the two.

23
00:01:08.793 --> 00:01:12.652
Now, a standard user is,
for the most part,

24
00:01:12.652 --> 00:01:17.760
they could do just about all
of their daily basic tasks.

25
00:01:17.760 --> 00:01:21.922
Run most of the software that
is within the operating system.

26
00:01:21.922 --> 00:01:25.435
They can make changes to their
personal user accounts but past that,

27
00:01:25.435 --> 00:01:27.627
they really can't do much more than that.

28
00:01:27.627 --> 00:01:30.441
Now the administrative
account on the other hand,

29
00:01:30.441 --> 00:01:34.893
we have to be careful with these accounts,
like a model, so many other operating

30
00:01:34.893 --> 00:01:39.082
systems follow the model ofthe most
powerful account has to be protected and

31
00:01:39.082 --> 00:01:41.100
for most parts it usually is.

32
00:01:41.100 --> 00:01:43.568
One of the things that has differed.

33
00:01:43.568 --> 00:01:47.778
For a while in Windows is the fact that
the default administrative account is

34
00:01:47.778 --> 00:01:48.450
disabled.

35
00:01:48.450 --> 00:01:50.860
And this is to better secure
the operating system,

36
00:01:50.860 --> 00:01:55.430
you never want somebody logging in as
the default administrative account because

37
00:01:55.430 --> 00:01:59.280
now they can do more than just run
their basic day to day applications.

38
00:01:59.280 --> 00:02:03.570
Now they can make changes to the core
functionality of the operating system and

39
00:02:03.570 --> 00:02:04.630
key security settings.

40
00:02:04.630 --> 00:02:08.480
So let's go ahead and look at
a concept known as an access token.

41
00:02:08.480 --> 00:02:11.050
It's one of the things
that we have to see here.

42
00:02:11.050 --> 00:02:14.760
So here on my machine we have
a standard user account.

43
00:02:14.760 --> 00:02:19.460
Now anytime a user logs in to a machine
they get what's known as a access token.

44
00:02:19.460 --> 00:02:22.960
And that access token is
applied to their account.

45
00:02:22.960 --> 00:02:26.640
From then on any time they try to
perform some kind of functionality

46
00:02:26.640 --> 00:02:30.528
within the operating system,
that access token is gonna be checked.

47
00:02:30.528 --> 00:02:34.340
And then the standard user token here, one
of the things you will notice is that it

48
00:02:34.340 --> 00:02:36.430
has what is known as
a security identifier.

49
00:02:36.430 --> 00:02:38.360
A few different security
identifiers in there.

50
00:02:38.360 --> 00:02:39.482
We call these SIDs.

51
00:02:39.482 --> 00:02:43.110
Now understand we as humans,
we typically don't see this information.

52
00:02:43.110 --> 00:02:45.590
What we see are group names,
we see user names.

53
00:02:45.590 --> 00:02:48.762
But the operating system underneath,
what it does,

54
00:02:48.762 --> 00:02:51.517
it sees this crazy long
string of characters.

55
00:02:51.517 --> 00:02:55.423
And you might have seen them come up
sometimes if you ever deleted an end user

56
00:02:55.423 --> 00:02:58.280
and it doesn't remove every
aspect of their account.

57
00:02:58.280 --> 00:03:01.540
Sometimes when you look at a permissions
list, you'll see this long block

58
00:03:01.540 --> 00:03:05.430
of numbers right after the letter S,
that's usually your security identifier.

59
00:03:05.430 --> 00:03:10.510
One of the things that I want you to
notice here is that the access tokens,

60
00:03:10.510 --> 00:03:13.020
standard access token, has the user's SID.

61
00:03:13.020 --> 00:03:16.460
It has every group security identifier and

62
00:03:16.460 --> 00:03:18.700
the different groups that
the user might be a part of.

63
00:03:18.700 --> 00:03:21.760
Now that's a little bit different
than the administrative account.

64
00:03:21.760 --> 00:03:26.391
When we look at the administrative
account when these accounts are created,

65
00:03:26.391 --> 00:03:31.096
what we end up having here is two access
tokens that are generated the moment you

66
00:03:31.096 --> 00:03:34.531
created an administrative account and
the user logs on.

67
00:03:34.531 --> 00:03:38.447
Now under something known as
the Standard User Security Architecture,

68
00:03:38.447 --> 00:03:39.800
now what does that mean?

69
00:03:39.800 --> 00:03:44.560
Well in the days of Vista,
they completely redid the architecture.

70
00:03:44.560 --> 00:03:46.115
So what does it mean for us?

71
00:03:46.115 --> 00:03:52.580
XP, typically, the first user by default
would be the administrative account.

72
00:03:52.580 --> 00:03:56.830
And here's something that caused a problem
back in those days is the fact that

73
00:03:56.830 --> 00:03:59.580
everybody would log in as the
administrator, the default administrator.

74
00:03:59.580 --> 00:04:02.370
Even standard users maybe didn't
even know much about the computer,

75
00:04:02.370 --> 00:04:04.570
they didn't even realize
that this was happening.

76
00:04:04.570 --> 00:04:09.930
So when they would log on, what would
happen was they would launch a program.

77
00:04:09.930 --> 00:04:11.477
When they launch this program,

78
00:04:11.477 --> 00:04:15.030
it would also run in the context
of their administrative account.

79
00:04:15.030 --> 00:04:18.060
And they would have access to things
like the kernel, the lower portions,

80
00:04:18.060 --> 00:04:20.978
the operating system,
things like executive services and

81
00:04:20.978 --> 00:04:22.722
Dan I could tell you one thing.

82
00:04:22.722 --> 00:04:26.414
If a standard user that doesn't know much
about a computer has full administrative

83
00:04:26.414 --> 00:04:30.176
access to that computer, a lot of times
that's going to start cause some problems.

84
00:04:30.176 --> 00:04:34.061
>> Oh yeah, unfortunately it's like
a child that's found its father's gun or

85
00:04:34.061 --> 00:04:37.050
something like that that have
great power in their hands and

86
00:04:37.050 --> 00:04:39.221
not a lot of maturity
to handle that power.

87
00:04:39.221 --> 00:04:42.860
So they think,
I'll just do whatever I want with it.

88
00:04:42.860 --> 00:04:44.240
And therein lies the problem.

89
00:04:44.240 --> 00:04:47.700
If I have admin level privileges,
what can't I do?

90
00:04:47.700 --> 00:04:49.870
Nothing.
I can do anything I want.

91
00:04:49.870 --> 00:04:51.460
I can install software.

92
00:04:51.460 --> 00:04:53.457
I can make changes to
the operating system.

93
00:04:53.457 --> 00:04:57.351
I can make changes to user accounts,
anything that I feel like doing,

94
00:04:57.351 --> 00:05:01.578
I have the rights to do, and the operating
system does not care whatsoever.

95
00:05:01.578 --> 00:05:05.178
It says hey you're an admin,
you must know what you're doing, so

96
00:05:05.178 --> 00:05:07.380
go ahead and shoot yourself in the foot.

97
00:05:07.380 --> 00:05:10.100
>> Yeah that's right and
that's typically usually what happens.

98
00:05:10.100 --> 00:05:14.409
If they can get access to something, even
if they're not trying to intentionally.

99
00:05:14.409 --> 00:05:15.344
Your standard users,

100
00:05:15.344 --> 00:05:18.742
that doesn't necessarily mean they come
to work everyday and say, hey, how can I

101
00:05:18.742 --> 00:05:22.191
figure out how to bring the whole network
down and give Dan and the administrators,

102
00:05:22.191 --> 00:05:25.115
myself a hard time, and then they
have to figure out what's going on.

103
00:05:25.115 --> 00:05:28.618
So, one of the things that Windows
has done for a while now, and

104
00:05:28.618 --> 00:05:30.482
it's included in Windows 10.

105
00:05:30.482 --> 00:05:33.030
It goes back all the way
to the days of Vista.

106
00:05:33.030 --> 00:05:34.470
Is they said, you know what?

107
00:05:34.470 --> 00:05:37.090
We've noticed that 90, and
I'm just throwing a number out here,

108
00:05:37.090 --> 00:05:41.240
I think it was like 80 to 90% of all
tasks that an end user would do,

109
00:05:41.240 --> 00:05:43.140
really didn't involve any
administrative privileges.

110
00:05:43.140 --> 00:05:45.690
So we implement a concept that
we've talked about here in

111
00:05:45.690 --> 00:05:50.180
Windows security quite a lot now called
the principal of least privilege.

112
00:05:50.180 --> 00:05:54.030
If you don't need that access, there's
no reason for it to be granted to you.

113
00:05:54.030 --> 00:05:56.591
Specially if you install
a program in the background and

114
00:05:56.591 --> 00:06:00.134
the program doesn't have some kind of
UI that's interactive that says hey,

115
00:06:00.134 --> 00:06:03.690
I'm modifying this, I'm modifying,
this, this, this, this and this.

116
00:06:03.690 --> 00:06:05.896
And before you know it,
everything's going haywire.

117
00:06:05.896 --> 00:06:10.491
So it is good to have every
user log in as a standard user.

118
00:06:10.491 --> 00:06:12.487
Now what do I mean by every user?

119
00:06:12.487 --> 00:06:16.701
Administrators also run as standard
users until they need those privileges.

120
00:06:16.701 --> 00:06:21.261
>> I was about to say Wes,
if I'm logging in as a standard user and

121
00:06:21.261 --> 00:06:24.614
I'm an administrator, how does that work?

122
00:06:24.614 --> 00:06:27.603
I don't have administrative privileges
on my standard user account,

123
00:06:27.603 --> 00:06:29.363
obviously because I'm a standard user.

124
00:06:29.363 --> 00:06:31.732
So how do I do administrative tasks?

125
00:06:31.732 --> 00:06:33.740
>> Well that's very good.

126
00:06:33.740 --> 00:06:37.290
If we go to our Windows machine here,
I'm logged in as, well, myself.

127
00:06:37.290 --> 00:06:38.395
I'm the first user here, and

128
00:06:38.395 --> 00:06:43.520
what's kind of interesting is the first
user in Windows Is the administrative user

129
00:06:43.520 --> 00:06:45.900
but every time I log in I
get those two access tokens.

130
00:06:45.900 --> 00:06:49.390
So that first standard user access token

131
00:06:49.390 --> 00:06:51.900
allows me to do the majority
of the stuff on the machine.

132
00:06:51.900 --> 00:06:53.760
But when I go to do things like for

133
00:06:53.760 --> 00:06:59.620
instance let's say install software that
might interact with the operating systems.

134
00:06:59.620 --> 00:07:00.530
Here's a good one.

135
00:07:00.530 --> 00:07:02.800
Everybody's got to have
a little Wireshark here.

136
00:07:02.800 --> 00:07:05.590
Now notice this little
shield that's going on.

137
00:07:05.590 --> 00:07:08.135
Now here is the user account control and
we're going to get to this in a second.

138
00:07:08.135 --> 00:07:09.877
We'll talk more about that.

139
00:07:09.877 --> 00:07:13.220
But what is going on is there's
a privilege escalation.

140
00:07:13.220 --> 00:07:18.887
I initiated this application
installer here as the standard user.

141
00:07:18.887 --> 00:07:23.424
At that point, my access token
doesn't contain the SID for

142
00:07:23.424 --> 00:07:25.694
an administrative account or

143
00:07:25.694 --> 00:07:31.155
the privileges that are associated
with the administrative account.

144
00:07:31.155 --> 00:07:34.685
But once I say yes to
the user account control.

145
00:07:34.685 --> 00:07:40.734
Now it's gonna ask me if I wanna install
this information or this program here.

146
00:07:40.734 --> 00:07:45.899
So one of the things to keep in mind is
that when you do run as an administrator,

147
00:07:45.899 --> 00:07:51.220
you're gonna run as a standard user until
you need those level of privileges.

148
00:07:51.220 --> 00:07:52.530
So what does it do for us?

149
00:07:52.530 --> 00:07:56.224
It keeps us safe, even as administrators,
we don't want things running

150
00:07:56.224 --> 00:07:59.265
in the background That could
potentially cause problems and

151
00:07:59.265 --> 00:08:01.247
could potentially ruin our machines.

152
00:08:01.247 --> 00:08:04.480
Let's go ahead and we're gonna log
in as our standard user here and

153
00:08:04.480 --> 00:08:08.464
we'll see how the user account control of
this administrative program works with

154
00:08:08.464 --> 00:08:09.460
the standard user.

155
00:08:09.460 --> 00:08:13.130
Now we've got our Wireshark
on the desktop here and

156
00:08:13.130 --> 00:08:15.680
we're logged back in as Old Billy.

157
00:08:15.680 --> 00:08:17.655
We'll see what Billy can do.

158
00:08:17.655 --> 00:08:19.101
Notice what's happening here.

159
00:08:19.101 --> 00:08:23.160
It is blocking me from the ability
to be able to run this program.

160
00:08:23.160 --> 00:08:27.626
Now the reason is, this program,
it's going to try to interact with

161
00:08:27.626 --> 00:08:32.179
the network protocol stack as
a Wireshark packet protocol analyzer.

162
00:08:32.179 --> 00:08:35.018
So it's gonna try to make some
modifications to the TCP/IP

163
00:08:35.018 --> 00:08:35.881
protocol stack.

164
00:08:35.881 --> 00:08:37.078
Well, in order to do that,

165
00:08:37.078 --> 00:08:41.040
you have to interact with something
known as the Windows filtering platform.

166
00:08:41.040 --> 00:08:43.580
And that's something only
an administrator can do.

167
00:08:43.580 --> 00:08:46.170
So what it's doing here is
checking Billy's access token.

168
00:08:46.170 --> 00:08:49.628
It's looking into that token,
like we see, and it's looking for

169
00:08:49.628 --> 00:08:52.594
an administrative SID,
an administrative privilege,

170
00:08:52.594 --> 00:08:56.198
and Windows is going you know what,
I'm just not finding that here.

171
00:08:56.198 --> 00:08:58.690
So it is blocking this from happening.

172
00:08:58.690 --> 00:09:02.410
And this is a good thing, because imagine
if you did have a program that was running

173
00:09:02.410 --> 00:09:05.050
in the background and
you didn't even see this going on,

174
00:09:05.050 --> 00:09:09.140
you wouldn't be aware that potentially
an application you have here

175
00:09:09.140 --> 00:09:13.690
is going to be making modifications
to your operating system.

176
00:09:13.690 --> 00:09:16.660
Now, the next thing I want to talk
about is that user account control that

177
00:09:16.660 --> 00:09:18.050
we've mentioned.

178
00:09:18.050 --> 00:09:21.606
Now, with the user account control,
I want you to keep in mind that what

179
00:09:21.606 --> 00:09:24.951
it does here is, there is a privilege
escalation that is going on.

180
00:09:24.951 --> 00:09:29.218
All right, with the privilege escalation,
it is looking for

181
00:09:29.218 --> 00:09:32.750
those administrative level privileges.

182
00:09:32.750 --> 00:09:36.240
Even if I am an administrator, it is still
looking at that standard access token and

183
00:09:36.240 --> 00:09:40.420
saying okay wait a second here,
I am looking for your privileges and

184
00:09:40.420 --> 00:09:41.580
I don't see them.

185
00:09:41.580 --> 00:09:45.325
Now once the user account control,
you interact with it.

186
00:09:45.325 --> 00:09:50.060
For instance, in the last demonstration
there, if I had my user account that I

187
00:09:50.060 --> 00:09:54.080
just type in my credentials,
it would elevate Billy's account,

188
00:09:54.080 --> 00:09:58.746
not with his access token but it would
grab my Administrative Access Token and

189
00:09:58.746 --> 00:10:01.800
apply it to the process
that happening right now.

190
00:10:01.800 --> 00:10:07.080
So Billy wouldn't just get my credentials
and be able to do whatever he wants.

191
00:10:07.080 --> 00:10:09.200
He would just be able to
install that software.

192
00:10:09.200 --> 00:10:12.800
Obviously, that's not
something that we want here.

193
00:10:12.800 --> 00:10:15.070
Now that brings up
the User Account Control.

194
00:10:15.070 --> 00:10:17.269
So what is the User Account Control
mean for us?

195
00:10:17.269 --> 00:10:20.490
Well the User Account Control,
it is a technology,

196
00:10:20.490 --> 00:10:23.280
another one that first
came around in Vista.

197
00:10:23.280 --> 00:10:26.960
And kind of thinking back to
the User Account Control,

198
00:10:26.960 --> 00:10:31.606
I know it was one of those things
that really everybody loved to hate.

199
00:10:31.606 --> 00:10:32.767
Why is that?

200
00:10:32.767 --> 00:10:36.897
Because in the days of XP, well,
everybody was running as an administrator,

201
00:10:36.897 --> 00:10:39.662
most of the programs those
days were coded that way.

202
00:10:39.662 --> 00:10:43.697
When the standard user security
architecture came out, it said uh-oh,

203
00:10:43.697 --> 00:10:46.230
now we're gonna change
around a little bit.

204
00:10:46.230 --> 00:10:49.870
Anytime an application runs, we're gonna
be looking for those credentials, and

205
00:10:49.870 --> 00:10:53.210
if it doesn't find those it's gonna
block that application from running.

206
00:10:53.210 --> 00:10:56.390
So we did have some
compatibility issues early on.

207
00:10:56.390 --> 00:10:58.344
Thank goodness today it has matured a lot,
so

208
00:10:58.344 --> 00:11:00.977
we don't have those application
compatibility problems.

209
00:11:00.977 --> 00:11:06.394
But there are a few different ways you
can configure the user account control.

210
00:11:06.394 --> 00:11:11.336
Now you do have to be an administrative
user in order to configure

211
00:11:11.336 --> 00:11:13.510
the user account control.

212
00:11:13.510 --> 00:11:18.728
So, let me just go ahead real quick and
we'll switch accounts here.

213
00:11:18.728 --> 00:11:20.920
Now there's a couple different
ways that you can do this.

214
00:11:20.920 --> 00:11:24.573
One of the basic ways that you can do
this is through the Control Panel.

215
00:11:24.573 --> 00:11:27.779
>> One of my favorite ways
is getting you to do it.

216
00:11:27.779 --> 00:11:28.348
>> [LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

217
00:11:28.348 --> 00:11:30.167
>> Hey, can you do this for me, Wes?

218
00:11:30.167 --> 00:11:32.216
>> [LAUGH] Yeah, that's right.

219
00:11:32.216 --> 00:11:35.080
Hurry up and email me here.

220
00:11:35.080 --> 00:11:38.850
You can email me at dan@itpro.tv.

221
00:11:38.850 --> 00:11:44.890
Now, the Control Panel is one
of the ways that's fairly easy.

222
00:11:44.890 --> 00:11:48.780
It allows you a basic set
of configurations, but

223
00:11:48.780 --> 00:11:49.940
it is kinda limited here.

224
00:11:49.940 --> 00:11:55.450
So, if we go over to the quick access
menu and choose Control Panel.

225
00:11:55.450 --> 00:11:59.240
We can go over here to User Accounts,
and then user accounts again.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explore securing your Windows 10 environment by using certificates. Here they explain some of the ways in which Windows 10 uses certificates for both the User and Machine to verify identity. Then they show how to work with certificates using the Certificate Manager. Lastly they explain what a Certificate Authority(CA) is and the difference between a Public and Private CA.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes explain how to secure the availability of your data by implementing good data redundancy practices through backup and recovery procedures. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Wes look at configuring a Windows 10 client to connect securely to a wireless network. First they go over the different encryption types (WEP/WPS/WPA/WPA2) that may be supported by any given access point. Then they jump to the Windows 10 client and configure things like the Windows Firewall profile as well as showing how to connect to a secure wireless network. They also demonstrate other wireless security measures like WiFi Sense and MAC filtering.

episodes.description: In this episode, Wes and Dan explore some of the ways you might securely connect to a private network from a remote location using Windows 10. They start by configuring a VPN connection using the Windows 10 VPN client and discuss the different protocols used to secure VPN connections; including Point to Point Tunneling Protocol(PPTP), Layer 2 Tunneling Protocol(L2TP), and Secure Sockets Tunneling Protocol(SSTP). They also look at authentication protocols, specifically MS-CHAP, MS-CHAPv2, and EAP; then finish up with Microsoft Direct Access.
